articles.headline: Why Russia Can’t Afford Another Cold War
articles.snippet: The old Soviet Union was all but impervious to foreign economic or business pressure. But now it has a stock market, and an economy heavily reliant on exports to Europe.
articles.abstract: The old Soviet Union was all but impervious to foreign economic or business pressure. But now it has a stock market, and an economy heavily reliant on exports to Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russian troops pour over a border. An autocratic Russian leader blames the United States and unspecified “radicals and nationalists” for meddling. A puppet leader pledges fealty to Moscow.

articles.headline: In Parched California, Town Taps Run Nearly Dry
articles.snippet: For the middle-class town Lake of the Woods, the absence of rain is posing a fundamental threat to drinking water.
articles.abstract: For the middle-class town Lake of the Woods, the absence of rain is posing a fundamental threat to drinking water.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKE OF THE WOODS, Calif. — People in this mountain town straddling the San Andreas Fault are used to scrapping for water. The lake for which it is named went dry 40 years ago. But now, this tiny community is dealing with its most unsettling threat yet: It could run out of water by summer.

articles.headline: After Debit Card Fraud, a Chicago Bank Feels Its Customers’ Frustration
articles.snippet: First American Bank in Chicago got publicity but little satisfaction after it identified a source of debit card theft and tried to stop it.
articles.abstract: First American Bank in Chicago got publicity but little satisfaction after it identified a source of debit card theft and tried to stop it.
articles.lead_paragraph: People should no longer use debit or credit cards in Chicago taxicabs. Bank of America should shut off the card-swiping terminals in the back of those cabs. And MasterCard ought to learn to share more information with its customers.

articles.headline: Is There a Doctor in the House? Yes, 17. And 3 in the Senate.
articles.snippet: A heightened political awareness, and a healthy self-regard that they could do a better job, are drawing a surprisingly large number of doctors to the power of elective office.
articles.abstract: A heightened political awareness, and a healthy self-regard that they could do a better job, are drawing a surprisingly large number of doctors to the power of elective office.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKE OSWEGO, Ore. — First thing on a recent Monday, Monica Wehby could be found in the operating room performing brain surgery on a child. But the Saturday before, she was shooting guns, because sometimes that’s what you do when you’re running for office.

articles.headline: Western Businesses in Russia, Watchful and Wary
articles.snippet: American players including Pepsi and McDonald’s are active in Russia. But for many West European businesses, that market is even more crucial.
articles.abstract: American players including Pepsi and McDonald’s are active in Russia. But for many West European businesses, that market is even more crucial.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Shortly after pro-Russian troops infiltrated Crimea last weekend, the phone in Alexis Rodzianko’s Moscow office started ringing. He is president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Russia, and local managers for some of the world’s biggest brands were calling to discuss the safety of their operations and the risks that might arise if the West were to impose sanctions.

articles.headline: Recall at G.M. Is Early Trial for New Chief
articles.snippet: Facing the recall of 1.6 million cars weeks into her tenure as chief executive, Mary T. Barra has taken the lead role in handling the crisis, starting an internal inquiry and ordering a rare public apology.
articles.abstract: Facing the recall of 1.6 million cars weeks into her tenure as chief executive, Mary T. Barra has taken the lead role in handling the crisis, starting an internal inquiry and ordering a rare public apology.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Only weeks into her tenure as chief executive of General Motors, Mary T. Barra has been increasingly consumed by a crisis over the recall of 1.6 million defective cars linked to 13 deaths.

articles.headline: Russia’s Move Into Ukraine Said to Be Born in Shadows
articles.snippet: The Kremlin’s strategy emerged haphazardly as an emotional President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia acted out of what officials called a deep sense of betrayal and grievance.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin’s strategy emerged haphazardly as an emotional President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia acted out of what officials called a deep sense of betrayal and grievance.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The day after he returned from the Winter Olympics, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia gathered the 12 members of his national security council for a crisis meeting to manage a political implosion in Ukraine that, by all accounts, had surprised Russia’s political and military elite and, above all, infuriated Mr. Putin himself.

articles.headline: Behind Clash Between C.I.A. and Congress, a Secret Report on Interrogations
articles.snippet: A dispute over a classified C.I.A. report has led to a bitter fight between the agency and the Senate Intelligence Committee, with each side accusing the other of spying on it.
articles.abstract: A dispute over a classified C.I.A. report has led to a bitter fight between the agency and the Senate Intelligence Committee, with each side accusing the other of spying on it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was early December when the Central Intelligence Agency began to suspect it had suffered what it regarded as an embarrassing computer breach.

articles.headline: Passport Theft Adds to Mystery of Missing Malaysia Airlines Jet
articles.snippet: At least two passengers used stolen passports to board a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared Saturday between Kuala Lumpur and Beijing with 239 people aboard, raising the unsettling possibility of foul play.
articles.abstract: At least two passengers used stolen passports to board a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared Saturday between Kuala Lumpur and Beijing with 239 people aboard, raising the unsettling possibility of foul play.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Investigators trying to find out what happened to a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared en route to Beijing on Saturday morning were examining the usual causes of plane crashes: mechanical failure, pilot error, bad weather. But the discovery that two of the passengers were carrying stolen passports also raised the unsettling possibility of foul play.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Whistle That’s Lost in the Crowd
articles.snippet: A bank loan investigation may yield no reward for the underwriter who sounded the alarm.
articles.abstract: A bank loan investigation may yield no reward for the underwriter who sounded the alarm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last month, deep in the annual financial statement filed by SunTrust Banks — on Page 197, to be exact — there was this nugget of news: The Justice Department is investigating mortgages that SunTrust, a large bank holding company operating in the Southeast, underwrote and sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the home loan finance giants.

articles.headline: The Youngest Technorati
articles.snippet: Teenage designers of apps and games have many incentives — financial and otherwise — to forget about their schoolwork.
articles.abstract: Teenage designers of apps and games have many incentives — financial and otherwise — to forget about their schoolwork.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ryan Orbuch, 16 years old, rolled a suitcase to the front door of his family’s house in Boulder, Colo., on a Friday morning a year ago. He was headed for the bus stop, then the airport, then Texas.

articles.headline: Mercy and Social Media Slow the Noose in Iran
articles.snippet: Public hangings still attract hundreds of onlookers, but Iran’s enormous middle class is turning against capital punishment.
articles.abstract: Public hangings still attract hundreds of onlookers, but Iran’s enormous middle class is turning against capital punishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Born into a poor family in one of Tehran’s most desolate neighborhoods, at age 17 Safar Anghouti had little to look forward to beyond a lifetime in his father’s business — rummaging through trash on the streets of the city for bottles, cans and anything else of value.

articles.headline: Auto Regulators Dismissed Defect Tied to 13 Deaths
articles.snippet: Federal safety regulators received more than 260 complaints over the last 11 years about General Motors vehicles that suddenly turned off, but they declined to investigate the problem.
articles.abstract: Federal safety regulators received more than 260 complaints over the last 11 years about General Motors vehicles that suddenly turned off, but they declined to investigate the problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal safety regulators received more than 260 complaints over the last 11 years about General Motors vehicles that suddenly turned off while being driven, but they declined to investigate the problem, which G.M. now says is linked to 13 deaths and requires the recall of more than 1.6 million cars worldwide.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout, Danielle Ivory and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Sovereignty vs. Self-Rule: Crimea Reignites Battle
articles.snippet: The showdown in Ukraine has revived a centuries-old debate over when secession is legitimate. Nations’ views vary greatly, depending on their own alliances and interests.
articles.abstract: The showdown in Ukraine has revived a centuries-old debate over when secession is legitimate. Nations’ views vary greatly, depending on their own alliances and interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They wanted to break away from a country they considered hostile. The central government cried foul, calling it a violation of international law. But with the help of a powerful foreign military, they succeeded in severing ties.

articles.headline: When Employees Confess, Sometimes Falsely
articles.snippet: In a drive against in-house theft, retailers’ interrogation tactics have come under fire.
articles.abstract: In a drive against in-house theft, retailers’ interrogation tactics have come under fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: When an AutoZone investigator approached Chris Polston, asking for his help investigating a theft, Mr. Polston was happy to oblige.

articles.headline: Search for Jet Compounds the Mystery
articles.snippet: Planes and ships from a half-dozen countries joined the search for the plane that vanished with 239 people, including two who apparently used stolen passports to board.
articles.abstract: Planes and ships from a half-dozen countries joined the search for the plane that vanished with 239 people, including two who apparently used stolen passports to board.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — More than 48 hours after Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 vanished, the mysteries over its fate have only multiplied.

articles.headline: Barely Keeping Up in TV’s New Golden Age
articles.snippet: The vast wasteland of television has been replaced by an excess of excellence that is fundamentally altering my media diet and threatening to consume my waking life in the process.
articles.abstract: The vast wasteland of television has been replaced by an excess of excellence that is fundamentally altering my media diet and threatening to consume my waking life in the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a friend at work told me I absolutely, positively must watch “Broad City” on Comedy Central, saying it was a slacker-infused hilarity.

articles.headline: Microsoft Pins Xbox One Hopes on Titanfall, a Sci-Fi Shooting Game
articles.snippet: The company is betting that a new game, Titanfall, will be enough of a hit to improve sales of the Xbox One and secure its influence in the video-game market.
articles.abstract: The company is betting that a new game, Titanfall, will be enough of a hit to improve sales of the Xbox One and secure its influence in the video-game market.
articles.lead_paragraph: A video game that depicts a battle between corporate mercenaries and local brigands in far-off space colonies has already won the hearts and minds of Microsoft executives.

articles.headline: Little-Known Health Act Fact: Prison Inmates Are Signing Up
articles.snippet: Inmates are taking advantage of the expansion of Medicaid that allows states to extend coverage to single and childless adults — a major part of the prison population.
articles.abstract: Inmates are taking advantage of the expansion of Medicaid that allows states to extend coverage to single and childless adults — a major part of the prison population.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a little-noticed outcome of President Obama’s Affordable Care Act, jails and prisons around the country are beginning to sign up inmates for health insurance under the law, taking advantage of the expansion of Medicaid that allows states to extend coverage to single and childless adults — a major part of the prison population.

articles.headline: Credit Suisse Documents Point to Mortgage Lapses
articles.snippet: A newly released trove of internal emails and documents, mostly from 2006 and 2007, paint a troubling picture of how Credit Suisse operated as the housing bubble inflated.
articles.abstract: A newly released trove of internal emails and documents, mostly from 2006 and 2007, paint a troubling picture of how Credit Suisse operated as the housing bubble inflated.
articles.lead_paragraph: The email from a Credit Suisse executive was blunt: The bank seemed to be pushing through risky home mortgages from questionable applicants.

articles.headline: After Fukushima, Utilities Prepare for Worst
articles.snippet: Exelon, which operates 17 of the 100 commercial power reactors in the United States, will spend $400 million to $500 million in post-Fukushima fixes.
articles.abstract: Exelon, which operates 17 of the 100 commercial power reactors in the United States, will spend $400 million to $500 million in post-Fukushima fixes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PEACH BOTTOM, Pa. — Stored near the twin nuclear reactors here, safely above the flood level of the Susquehanna River, is a gleaming new six-wheel pickup truck with a metal blade on the front that can plow away debris from an earthquake or other disaster. Attached to the back is a trailer that carries a giant diesel-powered pump that can deliver 500 gallons of water a minute.

articles.headline: Now Comes Hard Part for G.M.: The Repairs
articles.snippet: General Motors’ recall of 1.6 million cars is a time-consuming process with many steps, including designing and testing the new parts, finding and informing owners, then fixing the vehicles.
articles.abstract: General Motors’ recall of 1.6 million cars is a time-consuming process with many steps, including designing and testing the new parts, finding and informing owners, then fixing the vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than a month after General Motors announced it would recall 1.6 million cars because of a defective ignition switch, the automaker now faces an arduous task: fixing the cars.

articles.headline: 2 Star-Crossed Afghans Cling to Love, Even at Risk of Death
articles.snippet: Young people who want to choose their own mates face the harsh reality that strict social traditions still trump new laws and expanded rights — and that honor killings in such cases remain endemic.
articles.abstract: Young people who want to choose their own mates face the harsh reality that strict social traditions still trump new laws and expanded rights — and that honor killings in such cases remain endemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMIAN, Afghanistan — She is his Juliet and he is her Romeo, and her family has threatened to kill them both.

articles.headline: A Kiev Question: What Became of the Missing?
articles.snippet: Since protests began in Ukraine last December, 661 people have been reported missing, and the fates of 272 of them remained unknown late last week.
articles.abstract: Since protests began in Ukraine last December, 661 people have been reported missing, and the fates of 272 of them remained unknown late last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Volodymyr Danyluk was a Soviet Army veteran who joined demonstrations against Ukraine’s government last year. He was 55 years old, separated from his wife and mostly out of contact with his family, who saw him on live television during a winter of protests.

articles.headline: After Big Bet, Hedge Fund Pulls the Levers of Power
articles.snippet: The activist hedge fund manager William A. Ackman bet a billion dollars on the collapse of the nutritional supplement company Herbalife, then launched an extraordinary campaign to hasten that development.
articles.abstract: The activist hedge fund manager William A. Ackman bet a billion dollars on the collapse of the nutritional supplement company Herbalife, then launched an extraordinary campaign to hasten that development.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a Midtown Manhattan steakhouse last June, William A. Ackman, the activist hedge fund manager who had bet a billion dollars on the collapse of the nutritional supplement company Herbalife, offered his latest evidence to a handful of other hedge fund managers about why the company’s stock could soon plummet.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Eric Lipton and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Chiquita Buys Ireland’s Fyffes to Go Global in Banana Business
articles.snippet: The combined companies, which will be named ChiquitaFyffes, will be the world’s largest producer and distributor of bananas and will have about $4.6 billion in annual revenue.
articles.abstract: The combined companies, which will be named ChiquitaFyffes, will be the world’s largest producer and distributor of bananas and will have about $4.6 billion in annual revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:39 p.m. | The banana is the king of fruit, outselling apples, oranges and all the rest. And now the king of bananas will be Chiquita Brands International.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Stephanie Strom
